properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense frontal system will move across the BC Coast today and Tuesday. Showers have developed across the region this morning. These showers will continue today and are expected to intensify to heavy rain this evening over Howe Sound, Metro Vancouver, west and central Fraser Valley. Total rainfall accumulation of 60 to 90 mm is expected through Tuesday morning. The heavy rain will ease by midday Tuesday. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-08T04:49:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-07T12:50:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0521572220.2020
Area: Howe Sound, Metro Vancouver - North Shore including West Vancouver and North Vancouver, Metro Vancouver - central including the City of Vancouver Burnaby and New Westminster, Metro Vancouver - northeast including Coquitlam and Maple Ridge, Metro Vancouver - southeast including Surrey and Langley, Fraser Valley - west including Abbotsford, Fraser Valley - central including Chilliwack
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An additional 10 cm of snow is expected this morning. A frontal systems moving across the Gulf of Alaska continues to bring periods of heavy snow to the South Klondike highway near White Pass this morning. Gusty southerly winds combined with snow are producing blowing snow. The heavy snow is expected to ease to a few flurries this afternoon. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-08T05:12:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-07T13:22:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2069158737.2020
Area: South Klondike Highway - Carcross to White Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southwest winds of 90 to 100 kilometres per hour are forecast beginning this morning. These conditions will persist through Tuesday. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

Heavy rain will continue through Monday before easing midday Tuesday. Total rainfall accumulation of 60 to 90 mm is expected. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall continues. Total snowfall: 15 to 25 cm. Time span: this evening until overnight Monday. Locations: Upper Lake Melville area. Remarks: Snow is expected to be heaviest tonight, with snowfall rates easing on Monday. For anyone considering travel eastward: Very heavy snowfall is expected along the Trans-Labrador Highway between Happy Valley-Goose Bay and the coast. Road closures are possible. Please refer to warnings for these areas for further details. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 10 to 20 centimetres of additional snow, strong winds and blowing snow. An intense low pressure system over the Gulf of St Lawrence this evening will affect Eastern Quebec through Monday morning. This system will bring snow at times heavy overnight over several areas of the Gaspé Peninsula especially those near the river. This storm will also be accompanied by strong winds gusting up to 70 kilometres per hour. These winds combined with snow will reduce visibilities to near zero locally over these areas. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-07T13:59:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-07T02:51:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1919740601.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected in the Fort Providence region after midnight tonight. The freezing rain will end early in the morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A robust frontal system is pushing southwards towards the Columbia region. With temperatures below zero and ample moisture, heavy snow will begin this morning over North Columbia and Rogers Pass. As the frontal system continues to push south, heavy snow will start falling in East Columbia and Yoho Park later this afternoon. Total snowfall accumulation is expected to be 15 to 25 cm. The heavy snow will switch over the rain for North Columbia early Tuesday morning. Heavy snow will ease late Tuesday for Rogers Pass, Yoho Park and East Columbia. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind and rain likely for Tuesday night and Wednesday. Locations: The Avalon Peninsula. Possible rainfall: 15 to 30+ mm Winds: Generally northeasterly 40 gusting to 60 km/h with stronger coastal gusts. Some areas could see gusts approach 100 km/h on Wednesday as winds shift to northwesterly. Remarks: A deep low pressure system will track near the Avalon Peninsula. While it seems likely that precipitation will be mainly rain, the snow-rain line is expected to be near the isthmus. If the track were to shift further southeast, significant snowfall could be possible over the western Avalon. Rainfall warnings are unlikely at this point, since the ground is not frozen and there is no snow pack. Under these circumstances, 50 mm of rain in 24 hours would be required for a warning. Conditions will improve by Wednesday afternoon or evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-08T01:56:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-07T09:57:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1097785227.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant Snowfall for Tuesday night and Wednesday. Locations: Eastern half of the Island, excluding the Avalon and Burin peninsulas. Possible snowfall: Generally 10 to 20 cm with potential for higher amounts locally. Winds: Generally northeasterly 40 gusting to 60 km/h with stronger coastal gusts. Some areas along the south and east coasts could see gusts approach 100 km/h. Remarks: The cause of this disruption to our lack of winter weather will be a deep low pressure system passing near the Avalon Peninsula. Snow will begin on Tuesday evening and persist in some areas until Wednesday afternoon. Temperatures are expected to be near zero, which means areas along the coast may see the snow mix with or change completely over to rain. Unfortunately, this also means the snow is likely going to be rather wet and heavy. We will also likely see a period of freezing rain and ice pellets over the easternmost regions Tuesday night into Wednesday morning. Extra considerations for the Clarenville area and the Bonavista Peninsula: These areas are expected to be right along the snow-rain line. If the storm track shifts further northwest precipitation in these areas could easily be mostly rain, with up to 30 mm possible instead of snow, ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-08T01:55:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-07T09:56:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1508408018.2020
Area: Connaigre, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Gander and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions continue near the Richardson Mountains early this morning. Easterly winds of 70 gusting to 90 km/h near Rock River continue to give near zero visibility in snow and blowing snow. The strongest winds are expected to ease this morning bringing an end to blizzard conditions. However, gusty easterly winds will continue near the Richardson Mountains this afternoon and tonight. Local areas of blowing snow with reduced visibility are expected through tonight. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall continues. Additional snowfall: 10 to 15 cm from Norman Bay to Lodge Bay. 15 to 25 cm from Cartwright to Black Tickle. Time span: today and tonight. Locations: Cartwright to Lodge Bay. Remarks: The heaviest snow will continue to fall inland, with lesser amounts along the coast. The snow will mix with rain along parts of the coast between Norman Bay and Lodge Bay this morning. Strong northeasterly winds gusting to 60 km/h accompanying the snow will cause reduced visibility in blowing snow inland and over higher terrain today. For anyone considering travel: road closures are possible. Very heavy snowfall is expected along portions of the Trans-Labrador Highway. Please refer to warnings for adjacent areas for further details. Conditions will improve on Tuesday afternoon as snow tapers off to flurries. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
